column4: Recent research is trying to figure out how to make images accessible.
column10: What does this have to do with the content of the article? what is on the screen on the wall? are there examples of "black" and "white" consumer electronics?
column11: Nothing. I see no point to the graphic, so find no value in the description
column13: Not seeing the image, maybe the image is the problem more than thedescription
column22: I do not understand the questions that ask how well the description matches the image as I cannot see the image.
column28: Does the image highlight which parts of the building are its roof?
column30: Vague, image does not seem to add much to understanding of article but that could just be it is a bad image, not a bad description
column31: Hard to comment too much without seeing image.
column37: description does not match topic so no questions
column56: nothing in particular other than it was short
column57: just not very useful or interesting, but that again may be because the image itself is not useful or interesting
column66: did not match topic of article
column73: does the image feature any other forms of advertising?
column91: why not show/describe mountains themselves and the life on them?
column100: what does it have to do with furniture really?
column103: none of these images add much value and many like this one add none
column109: any other examples of competition portrayed?
column118: is there an example of a cross in the picture?
column127: none, offers little context for article
column130: not adding atg to understanding of article
column136: why even bother with such a vague description/
column138: vague and also not providing any important information
column145: Who cares about this image and what does it do to help one understand tableware?
column146: The description itself was quite good balancing detail without too much, but the image has nothing to do with the article so it is just a waste of time
column154: why not describe the water more since that is the focus?
column155: detials were good but focusedon less relevant parts of image
column163: irrelevant and I have no desire to understand the image further
column177: Always (More than 95% of the time you use computers)
column183: It seems like the images themselves were bad, not necessarily the descriptions. This study makes me question more than ever the value of having all images described. I would rather have good descriptions of a few important images than descriptions of all images I encounter. Also, it was hard to answer the questions as to how accurately the description captured the relevant aspects of the image. And what I really mean is it was impossible.
